Email                  | ID     | Password
abc@kent.edu | abc | hash(password)

Then we use ID to handle access control

author: Terrelle Tettey
message:
I just pushed the changes with docker set up already. @ashtoncorsello , Garrett and I were discussing using Mysql instead of sqlite as agreed on earlier. We plan to use an ORM (Object relational Mapping) called Peewee which should make the database development process easier.

Documentation:
http://docs.peeweeorm.com/en/latest/peewee/quickstart.html#model-definition

author: Garrett Stallsmith
message:
Here's the rewritten schema with improved clarity on the relationships between data:

CREATE TABLE Users (
    user_id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
    email TEXT UNIQUE NOT NULL
);

CREATE TABLE Groups (
    group_id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
    lab_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
    group_name TEXT NOT NULL,
    FOREIGN KEY (lab_id) REFERENCES Labs(lab_id)
);

CREATE TABLE LabPermissions (
    user_id TEXT NOT NULL,
    lab_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
    lab_admin INTEGER NOT NULL,
    FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES Users(user_id),
    FOREIGN KEY (lab_id) REFERENCES Labs(lab_id),
    PRIMARY KEY (user_id, lab_id)
);

CREATE TABLE Labs (
    lab_id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
    lab_name TEXT NOT NULL UNIQUE
);

Here are the changes made:

1. Renamed table "Credentials" to "Users" for clarity.
2. Renamed table "Lab-Permissions" to "LabPermissions" for consistency and readability.
3. Changed the data type of "lab_id" in "LabPermissions" to INTEGER to match the type in "Groups" and "Labs" tables for consistency.
4. Added foreign key constraints to enforce referential integrity between tables.
5. Made "user_id" and "lab_id" in "LabPermissions" table a composite primary key to ensure each combination is unique.
6. Removed redundant PRIMARY KEY declaration in the "Groups" table since it's a composite key with "group_id" as PRIMARY KEY.
7. Adjusted the table creation order to ensure foreign key constraints are properly referenced.

author: Garrett Stallsmith
message:
from peewee import *

Define your database connectiondatabase = SqliteDatabase('yourdatabasename.db')

Define your modelsclass BaseModel(Model):
    class Meta:
        database = database

class Users(BaseModel):
    user_id = CharField(primary_key=True)
    email = CharField(unique=True)

class Groups(BaseModel):
    group_id = AutoField(primary_key=True)
    lab_id = IntegerField()
    group_name = CharField()
    
    class Meta:
        indexes = (
            (('lab_id', 'group_name'), True),
        )

class LabPermissions(BaseModel):
    user_id = ForeignKeyField(Users)
    lab_id = ForeignKeyField(Groups)
    lab_admin = BooleanField()

    class Meta:
        primary_key = CompositeKey('user_id', 'lab_id')

class Labs(BaseModel):
    lab_id = AutoField(primary_key=True)
    lab_name = CharField(unique=True)

Create tables if they do not existdef create_tables():
    with database:
        database.create_tables([Users, Groups, LabPermissions, Labs])

Drop tables if they existdef drop_tables():
    with database:
        database.drop_tables([Users, Groups, LabPermissions, Labs])

Example of usageif __name == 'main':
    # Create tables
    create_tables()

author: Terrelle Tettey
message:
Just thought I'd put this here for reference

Docker Notes
Setup on Windows
https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-windows/install

Mac
https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-mac/install

Type these 2 commands to check if the installation is complete
docker version

docker compose version

If all is good, do:
docker run hello-world

If it’s successful, then you’re all set with the setup.



FOR OUR PROJECT:
docker build -t microqr_image .
docker run --name microqr -e TESTING=true -p "8080:5000" -d microqr_image
the above command should make it run on localhost:8080

author: ashtoncorsello
message: Alright so I got a lot of things working on my end. Right now, when you upload an image it returns the image and on each image there is a number (1-n). There is a dictionary printed next to it with the ID number that corresponds with the QR data. This dictionary is stored in “ids” in the homepage function in app.py. Also, there is now the ability to click on each individual qr code and you can receive the information attached to it. It is currently simply taking you to a missing webpage that is called “id”.html. Once we decide how we want to handle that I will make the function. My code is in Ashton-Dev branch. I’m currently working on testing the combining of my code with the current main branch, will update once it’s ready. I’m building the docker image, it’s taking a really long time so be prepared for that when it’s time to build. Lastly, I’m utilizing Chrome because the clicking on the QR codes isn’t working well in safari

author: ashtoncorsello
message: @Garrett Stallsmith i cant speak on any other parts, but id say the biggest reason for using redis is the ability to store much more data in the session than typically allowed. IDC if you have it in the slides or not but when talking about it make sure to mention thats why its being used. We are storing lots of information in the session to increase response time and allow for reloading of the edit page without uploading the scanned image again
